title: (x) 'Fringe': Victorian Decorative Display - Tuscan Ornate aka Bracelet, Lettres Ornées, Exotica, Romantiques {Mike Y, Tamas, F}
content:
Does anyone have any idea what these typefaces are... particularly the 'N'.... I'm pulling my hair out... I can't find anything remotely similar

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20110616144652im_/http:/typophile.com/files/BathFringe_3497.jpg)
author: cawood59

comments.content:
The G is called Tuscan Ornate, and Dan Solo has a digital version of it called Bracelet, which was another name for the typeface.

- Mike Yanega

The N is from a typeface called Lettres Ornées. (shown in Rookledge)

[edit: Dieter Steffmann has a version of this [here](http://web.archive.org/web/20110616144652/http:/www.moorstation.org/typoasis/designers/steffmann/samples/l/lettres.htm).]

- Mike Yanega

It seems to me I have seen a Dover book, maybe by Dan Solo with a collection of ornate initials like these. I suspect these have been scanned from a book like that.

- Mike Yanega

I have "Decorative Display Alphabets" by Dan X. Solo and it shows the N as a typeface he calls "Currier". I think the other name I gave is its original name.The book does not show any of these other letters, however.

- Mike Yanega
Lettres Ornées is still sold by [Stempel](http://web.archive.org/web/20110616144652/http:/www.schriftenservice-d-stempel.de/schrift.htm) as a metal typeface.
I have found the R [here](http://web.archive.org/web/20110616144652/http:/www.dafont.com/circus.font) as Circus, by Dan Roseman.

The E is [here, a few lines down](http://web.archive.org/web/20110616144652/http:/www.dafont.com/exotica.font?nb_ppp=50); I am starting to think the whole poster was culled together from the Decorative section of Dafont.

The R is not quite the same as Circus (check again), but you are right about Exotica for the E.

- Mike Yanega
The G is from Steffmann’s Romantiques.
